Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: Skier and skiër

English

[edit]

Etymology 1

[edit]

From ski +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈskiːə(ɹ)/
  • Audio (Southern England):(file)
  • Rhymes: -iːə(ɹ)

Noun

[edit]

skier (plural skiers)

  1. One who skis.
    a professional skier
    a poor skier
    • 2014, Alun Richardson, Rucksack Guide - Ski Mountaineering and Snowshoeing, page 126:
      Some ski instructors are allowed to take groups off-piste too, so long as they don't travel across glaciers, but the tour hosts and reps who commonly show skiers around pisted runs within large resorts are definitely not allowed to go off-piste […]
    • 2014, Patrick Armstrong, The Log of a Snow Survey, →ISBN:
      Townsend hare inhabit this area, particularly above the cabin, and a skier is likely to have one explode from a tree well and disappear into the whiteness as he skis by. Life is a constant bivouac for them -- they spend days huddled in tree wells during storms -- but I suspect they are as content and warm in their luxurious coats as we are in a cabin.
Derived terms
[edit]
  • alpine skier
  • cross-country skier
  • downhill skier
  • heli-skier
  • sit-skier
  • skier cross
  • skier-cross
  • skier day
  • skier X
  • skier-X
  • speed skier
  • technical skier
  • water-skier
Translations
[edit]
someone who practices skiing
  • Albanian: skiator (sq) m, skitar (sq) m
  • Arabic: مُتَزَحْلِق (ar) m (mutazaḥliq), مُتَزَحْلِقَة f (mutazaḥliqa)
  • Armenian: դահուկորդ (hy) (dahukord)
  • Azerbaijani: xizəkçi
  • Belarusian: лы́жнік m (lýžnik), лы́жніца f (lýžnica)
  • Bulgarian: скио́р m (skiór), скио́рка f (skiórka)
  • Catalan: esquiador m, esquiadora f
  • Chinese:
    Mandarin: 滑雪者 (huáxuězhě)
  • Czech: lyžař (cs) m, lyžařka (cs) f
  • Danish: skiløber (da) c, skiløberske c
  • Dutch: skiër (nl) m, skiester (nl) f
  • Esperanto: skiisto, (female) skiistino
  • Estonian: suusataja
  • Finnish: hiihtäjä (fi)
  • French: skieur (fr) m, skieuse (fr) f
  • Galician: esquiador m
  • Georgian: მეთხილამურე (metxilamure)
  • German: Skifahrer (de) m, Skifahrerin (de) f, Schifahrer (de) m, Schifahrerin (de) f, Schiläufer m, Schiläuferin f, Skiläufer (de) m, Skiläuferin (de) f
  • Greek: σκιέρ (el) m or f (skiér)
  • Hebrew: גּוֹלֵשׁ (he) m (golésh)
  • Hindi: स्कीयर m (skīyar)
  • Hungarian: síelő (hu)
  • Icelandic: skíðamaður m
  • Italian: sciatore (it) m, sciatrice (it) f
  • Japanese: スキーヤー (ja) (sukīyā)
  • Kazakh: шаңғышы (şañğyşy)
  • Korean: 스키어 (seukieo)
  • Kyrgyz: лыжачы (lıjacı), лыжник (lıjnik)
  • Latvian: slēpotājs m, skrējējs m (cross-country)
  • Lithuanian: slidininkas m
  • Macedonian: скијач m (skijač), скијачка f (skijačka)
  • Maori: kairetiwai (on water), kairerehuka (on snow), kairetireti huka (on snow)
  • Mongolian:
    Cyrillic: цаначин (mn) (canačin)
  • Norwegian:
    Bokmål: skiløper (no) m, skiløperske m or f, skigåer m
    Nynorsk: skilaupar m, skiløpar m, skiløypar m
  • Pannonian Rusyn: скияш m (skijaš)
  • Persian: اِسکی‌باز (eski-bâz)
  • Polish: narciarz (pl) m, narciarka (pl) f
  • Portuguese: esquiador (pt) m, esquiadora f
  • Romanian: schior (ro) m, schioară (ro) f
  • Russian: лы́жник (ru) m (lýžnik), лы́жница (ru) f (lýžnica)
  • Serbo-Croatian:
    Cyrillic: скѝја̄ш m, скија̀шица f
    Roman: skìjāš (sh) m, skijàšica (sh) f
  • Slovak: lyžiar m, lyžiarka f
  • Slovene: smučar m, smučarka f
  • Spanish: esquiador (es), esquiadora f
  • Swedish: skidåkare (sv) c, skidåkerska (sv) c
  • Tajik: лижарон (ližaron), лыжабоз (ližaboz)
  • Thai: นักสกี (nák-sà-gii)
  • Turkish: kayakçı (tr)
  • Ukrainian: ли́жник (uk) m (lýžnyk), ли́жниця (uk) f (lýžnycja)
  • Uzbek: changʻichi (uz)
  • Vietnamese: người trượt tuyết

Etymology 2

[edit]

From sky +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈskaɪə(ɹ)/
  • Rhymes: -aɪə(ɹ)

Noun

[edit]

skier (plural skiers)

  1. (cricket) A ball hit high in the air, often leading to a catch.
    • 2002, Jeff Green, "New Zealand win tri-series in convincing style", Cricinfo:
      However, when Guha returned, she picked the wrong ball to pull and hit a skier to Charlotte Edwards.
    • 2012, Harry Pearson, "There's always a catch – unless it's me or Monty underneath the ball", The Guardian:
      The second thing I did my best to get out of was the unpleasant position Monty found himself in rather too often in Sri Lanka: standing under a skier in the deep.

Anagrams

[edit]
  • kiers, Sirek, Kiser, keirs, siker, Keirs, Kiers, Rieks, Riske, keris, rikes, Rikes

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Norwegian ski.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /skje/, /ski.e/
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

skier

  1. to ski

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

[edit]

Norwegian Bokmål

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • ski

Noun

[edit]

skier m or f

  1. indefinite plural of ski

Polish

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈskjɛr/
  • Rhymes: -ɛr
  • Syllabification: skier

Noun

[edit]

skier f

  1. genitive plural of skra
